title: Pharmacokinetic considerations for certain groups
detail: • Ability to biotransform or eliminate drugs may be compromised in geriatric and younger patients, therefore drug doses are decreased or dose interval is increased

title: Pharmacodynamics
detail:
• Biochemical and physiologic effects of drugs
	• Mechanism of action (MOA): Drugs often “act” by interacting with a target protein like a receptor in a specific cell; agonists activate and antagonists block (exception are drugs that produce effects on the basis of their physical characteristics)
	• Side effects (adverse reactions): Commonly linked to MOA and result from the interaction of the drug with other cells than the target cell/tissue, alteration of patient’s physiology, or pharmacokinetics
Dose dependent reactions: Predictable, affects all, increase w dose
• Idiosyncratic drug reactions: Unpredictable, dose independent although risk increases w dose, often ass. w an immune system response

title: Therapeutic index (therapeutic ratio)
detail:
• Relative safety of a drug
• Expressed as
TI = LD50 / EC50
LD50 is the lethal dosage for 50% of a population
EC50 is the minimum effective concentration for 50% of the same population
• Higher the TI, safer the drug
• Low TI means the dosage range bw safe and toxic results is very small (few dosage options before adverse effects)

title: Therapeutic drug monitoring
detail: • Periodic measurement of the amount of a drug in the blood

title: Loading dose
detail:
• Initial administration of a large dose followed by smaller doses
• Brings serum concentration to a therapeutic level quickly
• Common w phenobarbital (anticonvulsant)

title: Anaphylactic shock
detail:
• An allergic reaction severe enough to cause death
• Low BP, itching, swelling, extreme respiratory problems
• Treated w IV diphenhydramine (Benadryl)

title: Antihistamines
detail:
• Drugs that block histamine release or reuptake
• Can prevent or reduce allergic reactions
• Multimodal therapy is common since allergy response involves multiple factors in the body
• Usually produce drowsiness, dry mouth, thirst

title: Mechanism of action for antihistamines
detail:
• Work by blocking H1 or H2 receptors
• H1 receptors are responsible for pruritus and movement of inflammatory cells to a site
• H2 receptors stimulate gastric acid secretion and regulate immune responses
• H1 blockers antagonize histamine at receptor sites (don’t block its release) (Benadryl, Claritin)
• Effective for anaphylaxis bc they stop bronchoconstriction and vasodilation
• Less effective as anti-inflammatory response or allergy treatment since histamines aren’t the only cause of inflammation
• H2 antagonists suppress gastric secretory effects and have mild anti-inflammatory effects (famotidine)

title: Antihistamine drugs
detail:
• Chlorpheniramine
• Cyproheptadine (used to enhance appetite in cats as well)
• Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
• Hydroxyzine
• Clemastine

title: Antimicrobial drugs
detail:
• Antibacterial drugs (antibiotics)
	• Vomiting and diarrhea most common side effect due to effects on GI flora and irritation of stomach
• Antifungal drugs
• Systemic (ketoconazole) or topical antifungals

title: Antibiotics
detail:
• Used to stop bacterial infections; bacteriostatic or bactericidal
• Broad spectrum antibiotics are effective against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but its overprescription is the reason for antibiotic resistance

title: Classes of antibiotic drugs (book 1)
detail:
• Beta-lactams
• Penicillins (end in -in)
• Cephalosporins (start w cef- or ceph-)
• Carbapenems
• Monobactams
• Chloramphenicol
• Lincosamides (e.g. clindamycin)
• Fluoroquinolones (end in -floxacin or -oxacin)
• Aminoglycosides (e.g. gentamicin, neomycin)
• Macrolides (e.g. erythromycin)
• Tetracyclines (end in -cycline or -tetracycline)

title: Classes of antibiotic drugs (book 2)
detail:
• Penicillins (G, V, Amoxicillin)
• Cephalosporins (Cefazolin, Cephalexin)
• Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin, Neomycin)
• Sulfonamides (Sulfadiazine)
• Fluoroquinolones (Enrofloxacin)
• Macrolides (Erythromycin)
• Linosamides (Clindamycin)
• Tetracyclines (Doxycycline)
• Nitromidazoles (Metronidazole)
• Macrolides (Chloramphenicol)

title: Beta-lactams
detail:
• Used in dogs, cats, poultry, and large animals to treat streptococcal and clostridial infections
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by targeting penicillin-binding proteins
• Penicillins and monobactams are narrow spectrum
• Carbapenems are broad spectrum
• Cephalosporins depend on generation—1st gen are narrow, 2nd to 4th are broad
• 1st gen include cefazolin, cephalexin; should not be used in animals allergic to penicillin

title: Chloramphenicol
detail:
• Used in pets to treat anaerobic infections including middle and inner ear and eye infections, and salmonellosis
• Bacteriostatic
• Broad spectrum
• Inhibits protein synthesis
• Illegal to use on food animals bc it’s known to cause aplastic anemia in humans
• Side effects include V/D, anaphylaxis

title: Lincosamides
detail:
• Bactericidal or bacteriostatic depending on species and severity of infection
• Moderate spectrum
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Effective against most anaerobes
• Include clindamycin, lincomycin
• Not used on horses

title: Fluoroquinolones
detail:
• Used in cats, dogs, ruminants, pigs, horses
• Can be used to treat infections of the skin, bladder, ears, kidneys, lungs (pneumonia), and prostate
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit nucleic acid synthesis
• Mostly narrow spectrum, except 3rd gen broad spectrum
• Include ciprofloxacin, enrofloxacin, etc.

title: Aminoglycosides
detail:
• Used to treat severe infection only bc they are nephrotoxic and ototoxic
• Used to treat Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli)
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Broad spectrum, but not effective against anaerobic bacteria
• Include gentamicin, amikacin, neomycin
• Severely nephrotoxic when administered by injection, but not absorbed systemically when given PO and poorly absorbed when applied topically, so these routes used often

title: Macrolides
detail:
• Used to treat respiratory issues, skin/soft tissue infections (staph/strep), GI infections (swine dysentery), and specific conditions like eye infections in cats
• Bacteriostatic (unless at high concentrations)
• Narrow spectrum (gram-positive)
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Include erythromycin, which is used in case of penicillin allergy

title: Tetracyclines
detail:
• Used to treat local and systemic infections, but resistance increased a lot
• Bacteriostatic
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Broad spectrum
• Effective against mycoplasma, spirochetes, chlamydia, and rickettsial diseases like Rocky Mountain spotted fever
• Include doxycycline, oxytetracycline, chlortetracycline

title: Antifungals
detail:
• Work by distinguishing mammalian cells from fungi cells (mammalian cell walls contain cholesterol, fungi cell walls contain ergosterol)
• Polyenes work by making fungi cell wall permeable, causing contents to spill out, resulting in cell death
• Azoles work by blocking the essential enzyme for cell wall synthesis, resulting in the loss of cell wall integrity
• Azoles include imidazole and triazole
• Triazoles preferred due to less effects and better results; include flucanozole and itraconazole
• Imidazoles include miconazole and ketoconazole
• Allylamines are used to treat dermatophytosis (ringworm); include terbinafine

title: Classes of antifungal drugs
detail:
• Polyenes
• Azoles
• Triazoles (flucanozole, itraconazole)
• Imidazoles (miconazole, ketoconazole)
• Allylamines (terbinafine)

title: Antiparasitics
detail:
• Bemzimidazoles (Fenbendazole) – nematodes, lungworms, cestodes, giardia
• Tetrahydropyrimidines (Pyrantel) – nematodes
• Prazinquantel – cestodes, trematodes
• Avermectins (Ivermectin, Sekamection) and Milbemycins (moxidectin) – nematodes, arthropods
• Metronidazole – giardia, balantidium coli

title: Moxidectin
detail:
• Antiparasitic in the class milbemycin
• Preventive for D. immitis in dogs; eliminates tissue stage of heartworm larvae; microfilaricide
• Closely related to avermectins

title: Ivermectin
detail:
• Monthly preventive for dogs and cats
• Plus formula (Heartgard Plus) in dogs is effective against hookworms and roundworms
• In cats, preventive for D. immitis and removal of hookworms

title: Pyrantel
detail:
• Used in dogs to remove tapeworms, hookworms, roundworms, whipworms
• Drug class tetrahydropyrimidines

title: Microfilariae
detail: • Immature heartworms

title: Macrocyclic lactones
detail:
• Avermectins and milbemycins
• Broad spectrum; various nematodes and arthropods, also as heartworm preventive in dogs
• Some species are sensitive (Collies) so used with caution in dogs

title: Ectoparasiticides
detail:
• Contact insecticides (pyrethrins, indoxacarb, lime sulfur)
• Drugs that target parasite’s nervous system (amitraz, avermectins)
• Insect growth regulators (lufeneron, pyripoxifen)

title: Heartworm treatment
detail:
• Multimodal treatment—an adulticide to kill off the adult HWs, ivermectin to eliminate larvae, an anti-inflammatory to minimize inflammation associated w HW presence, and a doxycycline to reduce numbers of Wolbachia
Case: Ivermectin + Melarsomine + Glucocorticoid + Prednisone + Doxycycline
• Exercise restriction is essential since pulmonary embolism from dead worms is a risk

title: Types of vaccines
detail:
• Live vaccines (aka modified or attuned vaccines): Strong immune response, most protection; strict storage and handling requirements
• Killed (inactivated) vaccines: Lesser immune response due to killed pathogen; usually requires 2 doses initially, followed by annual vaccination; more stable and easier to store
• Recombinant (DNA) vaccines: Non-disease-causing components produced by the pathogen are transmitted to a different organism that is introduced to the animal (immune system recognizes the same component in the pathogen and starts a response)
• Toxoid vaccines: Short-lived humoral immune response resulting from attenuated toxins

title: Antigens
detail:
• Protein molecules found on the outer surface of disease-causing pathogens
• Cause the body to create antibodies to fight disease

title: Anaphylactic reaction to vaccines
detail:
• Normally happen w/in 24 hours
• Can happen on the 1st vaccine or later
• Causes itching, weakness, apnea, sudden V/D, facial swelling, pale gums, seizures
• If untreated, can lead to respiratory and heart failure, shock
• Tx w epinephrine, antihistamines, oxygen therapy, IV fluids if needed

title: Antiarrhythmic drugs
detail:
• Used to restore normal electrical activity in the heart
• Sodium channel blockers (lidocaine and procainamide) limit the flow of sodium, slowing down conduction; used mainly for ventricular arrhythmias
• Beta-adrenergic blockers (propranolol) obstruct beta-adrenergic receptors which reduces sympathetic stimulation of the heart, decreasing HR and AV conduction
• Also negative inotropes (decrease contractility)
• Calcium channel blockers (verapamil and diltiazem) slow down conduction and prolong refractory periods; used mainly for supraventricular arrhythmias
• Also negative inotropes (decrease contractility)
• Positive inotropes (digoxin and catecholamines) make heart contractions stronger, improving cardiac output

title: Lidocaine
detail: • Myocardium's response to lidocaine and other class 1 antiarrhythmic drugs depends on the presence of potassium; hypokalemia will decrease efficacy

title: Anticoagulants and thrombolytics
detail:
• Blood clots are formed during coagulation by the protein thrombin, which is an enzyme that increases conversion rate of fibrinogen to fibrin (which induces the blood to clot)
• Anticoagulants stop formation of blood clots
• Thrombolytics break up and dissolve blood clots by activating plasmin, the enzyme that separates and disintegrates fibrin strands
• Heparin inhibits clot formation by stopping thrombin, but doesn’t break up existing clots
• Thrombolytics include t-PA (alteplase Activase), streptokinase, and urokinase
• Anticoagulants are more effective in treating thromboembolism in animals

title: Heparin
detail:
• Anticoagulant
• Found in tissues; obtained from pig intestinal mucosa
• Prevents conversion of prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin, w/out which fibrinogen won’t be converted to fibrin so clot won’t be formed
• Unfractionated heparin blocks the activity of thrombin, low molecular weight heparin doesn’t

title: Hemoglobin
detail:
• Iron-containing protein in RBCs
• Crucial for transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide

title: Hematics
detail:
• Blood-building products
• Used to treat anemia (low hemoglobin)
• Three types include erythropoietin (aka hematopoietin or hemopoietin), androgens, and blood substitutes
• Androgens stimulate kidney’s production of erythropoietin but have secondary effects so use is limited

title: Erythropoietin
detail:
• Hormone produced by the kidney, and to a lesser extent the liver if levels go down
• Regulates production of RBCs; stimulates bone marrow to produce RBCs
• Insufficient production will lead to anemia
• Renal diseases causes a decrease in its production so supplementation may be beneficial

title: Oxyglobin
detail:
• A blood substitute that can be given to anemic animals
• Derived from chemically stabilized bovine hemoglobin
• Short-term increase and maintenance of oxygen levels

title: Use of crystalloid and colloid solutions
detail:
• Isotonic solutions are used to support perfusion and volume replacement
• Hypertonic solutions are used to draw fluid from intracellular space to intravascular space; useful when large amounts of fluids are needed quickly
• Hypotonic solutions are used to move fluid from intravascular space to intracellular space; mostly used to correct electrolyte imbalances
• Colloids are used to restore organ perfusion; used in pulmonary contusions and head trauma; resuscitation is achieved w a lower rate since colloids stay in the vascular space longer than crystalloids

title: Blood products
detail:
• Fresh whole blood: Used in hemorrhagic shock, anemia, excessive surgical hemorrhage, clotting disorders, non-IMHA, sometimes IMHA
• Crystalloids combined w packed RBCs: Used when fluid balance and osmotic pressure need to be maintained (crystalloids used to expand blood volume)

title: Analgesics
detail:
• NSAIDs (phenylbutazone, aspirin, ibuprofen, etodolac, carprofen, flunixin)
• Opioids (morphine, meperidine, butorphanol, codeine)
• Corticosteroids (prednisone, dexamethasone)

title: Opioids
detail:
• Pure mu agonists: More effective analgesia, but side effects like vomiting, respiratory depression, sedation; include morphine, hydromorphone, fentanyl, meperidine
• Simbadol is a high-concentration buprenorphine w 24-hour action if given sc (6 hrs if IM); used in cats but metabolized in the liver so not for liver disease
• Partial mu agonists: Bind w the less effective analgesic receptor (k receptor); include buprenorphine
• Mu antagonist: Reverses the effects of pure mu agonists, weakening analgesic effects; include butorphanol

title: Common side effects of opioids
detail:
• Bradycardia
• Respiratory depression
• Hypotension
• Excitement
• Vomiting

title: NSAIDs
detail:
• Block production of prostaglandins that promote pain and inflammation
• Reduction of pain is thru reduction of inflammation that triggers the pain sensation
• Also have antipyretic effects
• Baseline and annual blood work to check kidney and liver function is necessary for long-term use
• Side effects include kidney and liver toxicity, GI ulcers, stomach bleeding, V/D, loss of appetite, lethargy

title: Benzodiazepines
detail:
• Sedatives w muscle relaxation
• Provide sedation by depressing the limbic system, thalamus, and hypothalamus
• Muscle-relaxing effects due to inhibition of neurons on the spinal cord
• Some like diazepam are anticonvulsants too
• Metabolized thru the liver and excreted thru urine, so caution in liver and kidney disease
• Side effects include CNS depression, ataxia, weakness, disorientation, nausea, vomiting
• Excitation right before depression possible

title: Alpha 2 agonists
detail:
• Sedatives that provide analgesia and muscle relaxation
• Cardiovascular effects like bradycardia, hypertension, and reduced cardiac output possible
• Not to be used in cardiovascular, liver, and kidney disease
• Include medetomidine (Domitor), dexmedetomidine, xylazine

title: Medetomidine
detail:
• Domitor
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Potent anxiolytic, hypnotic, anticonvulsant, muscle relaxant, sedative, analgesic
• Side effects include bradycardia, hypothermia, decreased respiration, urination, AV blocks, vomiting
• Caution especially in very young/old animals
• Reversed w atipamezole (Antisedan)

title: Dexmedetomidine
detail:
• Dexdomitor
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Premed for general anesthesia
• Side effects include bradycardia and hypertension—the hypertension results in a reflex bradycardia, which is why patients can have low HR coupled w normal BP
• Reversed w atipamezole (Antisedan)

title: Atipamezole
detail:
• Can cause transient behavioral problems like extreme nervousness
• Can cause hypotension so BP should be monitored
• HR and RR may increase
• Nausea and vomiting possible
• Diarrhea, hypersalivation, shivering, overstimulation possible
• Not for pregnant and nursing animals

title: Xylazine
detail:
• Rompun, Anased
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Analgesic, muscle relaxant, anesthesia, sedation
• Side effects include bradycardia, cardiac conduction disturbances, myocardial depression, vomiting
• Reversed w xylazine and yohimbine

title: Anticonvulsants
detail:
• Phenobarbital for long-term seizure control (oral)
• Potassium bromide and sodium bromide can be used in addition in dogs if phenobarbital alone isn’t enough or can’t be used
• Common side effect of phenobarbital is hepatotoxicity, so can’t be used in pre-existing liver disease

title: Antidepressants
detail:
• Clomipramine (Clomicalm) used for separation anxiety
• Selegeline (Anipryl) used for canine cognitive dysfunction

title: Cholinergic vs. adrenergic
detail:
• Adrenergic agents stimulate sympathetic processes, principally by releasing epinephrine and norepinephrine
• Cholinergic agents engage the parasympathetic processes, principally by producing, altering, mimicking, or releasing acetylcholine
• Adrenergic blockers and anticholinergics can be used to circumvent the agents

title: Anticholinergics
detail:
• Used to bock nerve impulses from reaching the vagus nerve
• Aminopentamide slows down GI motility
• Atropine and glycopyrrolate increase HR, dilate pupils, dry up secretions
• Can be used alongside opioids
• Not in case of high risk for tachycardia (often geriatric patients), history of CHF, or patients w constipation or ileus

title: Emetics
detail:
• Work by irritating the gastric mucosa, which stimulates the CNS and causes vomiting
• Include apomorphine and hydrogen peroxide (avoided in cats bc can cause hemorrhagic gastritis)
• Xylazine is the most effective emetic in cats
• Syrup of ipecac is not effective in cats; can cause cardiotoxic arrhythmias

title: Antiemetics
detail:
• Metoclopramide and aminopentamide for GI spasms
• Chlorpromazine, diphenhydramine, aminopentamide for motion sickness
• Maropitant citrate (Cerenia) is a NK-1 antagonist that works by blocking substance P in the chemoreceptor trigger zone, so used most commonly for motion sickness and many other instances of vomiting

title: Antidiarrheals
detail:
• Loperamide
• Diphenoxylate
• Aminopentamide
• Bismuth
• Kaolin
• Pectin
• Activated charcoal

title: Laxatives
detail:
• Bulk laxatives use insoluble, water-absorbing fiber that moves stool along once swollen by water
• Emollient laxatives soften stool by using a surfactant like docusate
• May take a week to take effect
• Include lubricants like mineral oil, white petrolatum, glycerin, cod liver oil, which ease the friction between stool and intestinal tract

title: Cathartics
detail:
• Osmotic (saline) cathartics induce movement of water into the small intestines, thereby draining lower intestines of content
• Hyperosmotic cathartics draw water from surrounding tissues to soften the feces; include magnesium salts and some disaccharides like lactulose (not digestible)
• Irritant cathartics irritate the bowel, thereby increasing peristalsis; include castor oil and bisacodyl
• Contraindicated in obstructed bowel and tenesmus

title: Antiulcer drugs
detail:
• Antacids
• H2-receptor blockers
• Proton pump inhibitors
• Cytoprotective agents

title: Antacids
detail:
• Reduce acidity in the stomach, lessening heartburn (pyrosis)
• Usually produce a chemical buffer that results in a rise in gastric pH measurements, leading to reflux not burning
• Commonly contain calcium, magnesium, aluminum

title: H2-receptor blockers
detail:
• Reduce the amount of gastric acid
• Histamine is the most important positive regulator of secretion of gastric acid (although not the only one, so acid will still be produced); w/out histamine proton pump can’t produce acid as readily and when acid levels fall ulcers can heal
• Include cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine (Pepsin)

title: Famotidine
detail:
• Pepsin
• H2-receptor blocker, so should be administered 1 hour after sucralfate to prevent changing the acidic environment of the stomach and inhibiting its binding to ulcers

title: Proton pump inhibitors
detail:
• Gastric hydrogen potassium ATPase enzyme is an enzyme that functions to acidify the stomach; also called stomach’s proton pump bc acid is measured by the number of protons in the stomach
• Proton pump inhibitors denature this enzyme and stop acid production by 99%
• Indicated for animals that don’t respond to antacids and H2-receptor blockers
• Include omeprazole

title: Sucralfate (Carafate)
detail: • Creates a protective lining along the surface of where the ulcer is formed

title: Endocrine drugs
detail:
• Thyroid drugs:
	• Hypothyroidism: Common in dogs and horses, treated w levothyroxine (T4)
	• Hyperthyroidism: Common in cats, treated w methimazole or radioactive iodine
• Adrenal drugs: Manage cortisol
	• Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing): In dogs and horses, treated w mitotane or trilostane
	• Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison): Can be spontaneous in dogs, or result from Cushing treatment, treated w fludrocortisone or prednisone+desoxycorticosterone pivalte
• Insulin

title: Production of thyroid hormones
detail:
• Hypothalamus releases thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH)
• TRH stimulates the pituitary to release thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
• TSH stimulates the thyroid to produce T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxin)

title: Symptoms of hyperthyroidism
detail:
• Mostly in felines
• Weight loss
• Increased appetite
• Thirst
• Excessive urination
• Heart murmur and elevated HR possible

title: Hyperthyroidism drugs
detail:
• Antithyroid agents include methimazole (Tapazole)
• Obstruct enzymatic processes in the thyroid so T3 and T4 aren’t produced
• Side effects include vomiting, malaise, fatigue
• Radioactive iodine treatments
• Thyroid is the only organ that requires iodine to function, and absorbs radioactive iodine just like normal iodine (and in larger quantities bc it’s abnormal tissue)
• Radiation then destroys the tumor and/or reduces the number of hormone-producing cells

title: Hypothyroidism symptoms
detail:
• Mostly in dogs; more in large dogs
• Excessive weight gain, leading to compromised joints and compromised cardiac and respiratory status
• Thinning and dull fur
• Flakey skin and nails
• Alopecia
• Skin hyperpigmentation
• Anemia
• High blood cholesterol
• Constipation
• Poor blood clotting
• Susceptibility to infections
• Depression and mental dullness
• Cold intolerance
• Mild bradycardia

title: Hypothyroidism drugs
detail:
• Supplemental thyroid hormones
• Natural from pigs, or synthetic
• T3 dosage is hard to regulate, so T4 is common (thyroid will transform some of it to T3

title: Reproductive drugs
detail:
• Estrogen: Steroid hormones that promote female characteristics
• Estrogen diethylstilbestrol (DES): Synthetic; prevents pregnancy by causing reabsorption of fertilized egg; may cause bone marrow suppression, pyometra
• Estradiol cypionate (ECP): Semi-synthetic; used in hormone replacement therapy, to prevent embryo implantation w/in 72 hr of mating, and treat urinary incontinence
• Oxytocin: Facilitates birthing by contracting uterus and milk production
• Prostaglandin: Controls length of time that corpus luteum exists (necessary to establish and maintain pregnancy); synthetic version dinoprost accelerates birthing process
• Progestin: Suppresses estrous—prevents start of proestrus to diminish sexual activity; include megestrol acetate

title: Megestrol acetate
detail:
• Progestin
• Used for behavioral problems like inappropriate urination in cats and as a contraceptive in dogs

title: Insulin
detail:
• Polypeptide hormone secreted by beta cells found in the islet of Langerhans (pancreas)
• Responsible for moving glucose out of the blood and into the cells for it to be used in energy production and stored for later use

title: Diabetes mellitus
detail:
• Type 1 (insulin-dependent DM) is caused by damage to pancreatic beta cells, which result in decreased insulin production; common in dogs
• Type 2 (non-insulin-dependent DM) is a decreased sensitivity to the amount of insulin produced; common in cats

title: Insulin drugs
detail:
• Fast-acting insulin (Vetsulin) is given when a patient needs blood sugars decreased rapidly
• NPH is used for daily control of insulin; classified as an intermediate-acting hormone
• Protamine zinc insulin is a combination of insulin and protamine, which results in an extended-release product
• Insulin facilitators are used in animals that produce some natural insulin
• Glipizide (Glucotrol) is a sulfonylurea-based antidiabetic (for type-1 DM)

title: Insulin syringes
detail:
• Insulin can only be given by injection
• Syringes are designed for administration of a given solution strength
• U-40 is used if patient needs 40 units of insulin
• U-100 is used if patient needs 100 units of insulin
• Wrong syringe can result in death

title: Administering insulin
detail:
• Should always be given after food to avoid hypoglycemia and seizures
• Should be stored in the refrigerator
• Only Vetsulin must be shaken, others should never be shaken bc shaking will damage the proteins and render insulin useless
• Injection sites can be rotated to prevent formation of sores and anticipation of pain

title: Tx of diabetic ketoacidosis
detail:
• DKA occurs when ketone bodies derived from fatty acids are used as an energy source instead of glucose (when glucose can’t be moved in and out of cells), which leads to acidic blood and rising levels of ketones that may lead to toxicity
• Fruity smelling breath is a sign
• IV fluids and insulin therapy necessary

title: Immunosuppressants
detail:
• Used to diminish effects of an overactive immune system (e.g. due to autoimmune diseases) and to help body accept organ donation
• Autoimmune diseases include IMHA, autoimmune thyroiditis, autoimmune adrenalitis, myasthenia gravis, skin autoimmune diseases

title: Immunosuppressant drugs
detail:
• Glucocorticoids (prednisone)
• Azathioprine
• Cyclosporine
• Mycophenolate mofetil
• Leflunomide
• Cyclophosphamide

title: Immunostimulants
detail:
• Used to increase immune responses against viruses and cancer cells
• Diseases most commonly treated w immunostimulants are feline leukemia virus, feline immunodeficiency virus, and canine lymphoma

title: Immunostimulant drugs
detail:
• CL/Mab 321: Canine lymphoma monoclonal antibodies
• Acemannan (Immunoregulin): For treatment of FIV, FLV, and some cancers

title: GI Drugs
detail:
• Antiemetics: metoclopramide, maropitant citrate, mirtazapine
• Emetics: xylazine, apomorphine
• Antidiarrheals: loperamide, pectin, probiotics
• Laxatives: lactulose, magnesium sulfate/hydroxide, castor oil, psyllium, petroleum products
• Prokinetics: Increase peristalsis in constipation or ileus; cisapride, metoclopramide
• Antiacids, antiulcers: omeprazole, sucralfate, ranitidine
• Appetite stimulants: mirtazapine
• Digestive enzyme supplements: pancrealipase

title: Cardiovascular drugs
detail:
• Diuretics: Reduce fluid accumulation (edema) by increasing sodium and water excretion (furosemide, spironolactone)
• Inotropic agents (+ive intotropes): Improve contractility of heart muscle (pimobendan (also vasodilator), digoxine)
• Antihypertensives: Modulate BP by dilating blood vessels (ACE inhibitors (enalapril), calcium channel blockers, etc.)
• Antiarrhythmics: Control rhythm abnormalities; I-IV (I: blockade of fast sodium channels-lidocaine; 2: beta-adrenergic blockade-propranolol, atenolol; 3: potassium channel blockers-sotalol; 4: calcium channel blockade-diltiazem)
• + Anticoagulants: Heparin, aspirin (slow metabolism in cats), clopidogrel

title: Diuretics
detail:
• Remove excess extracellular fluid by increasing urine flow and sodium secretion and by reducing hypertension
• Loop diuretics work fast—inhibit tubular reabsorption of sodium and promote excretion of chloride, potassium and water; used to treat CHF, pulmonary edema, udder edema (e.g. Furosemide (Lasix))
• Osmotic diuretics exert high osmotic pressure in tubules thus limiting tubular absorption; used to treat oliguric acute renal failure and reduce intracranial pressure (e.g. Mannitol (Osmitrol))
• Thiazide diuretics inhibit reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water; ued to treat hypertension and nephrogonic diabetes in dogs (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide (HydroDIURIL))
• Ppotassium-sparing diuretics are weaker; aka aldosterone antagonists, which allows them to excrete water and sodium and reduce excretion of potassium; used in CHF, hypertension, etc. (e.g. Spirolactone (Aldactone))

title: Respiratory drugs
detail:
• Antitussives: butorphanol, hydrocodone, dextromethorphan
• Expectorants: guaifenesin
• Mucolytics: acetylcysteine
• Decongestants: pseudoephedrine
• Bronchodilators: albuterol, aminophylline, diphenhydramine; terbutaline, metaproterenol
• Respiratory stimulants: doxampram

title: Respiratory agents
detail:
• Antihistamines to limit histamine’s effect on respiration
• Corticosteroids in case of severe lung inflammation
• Diuretics in case of excess fluid in the lungs
• Supplemental oxygen if breathing is compromised
• Stimulants (Doxapram) to increase respiratory function

title: Cough medications
detail:
• Antitussives: Used to reduce cough reflex in case of dry cough; contraindicated in productive coughs; include codeine
• Also used to treat kennel cough (tracheobronchitis)
• Include butorphanol, dextromethorphan, hydrocodone
• Expectorants: Aids in clearing congestion in productive cough by increasing fluidity of mucus so it can be expelled
• Mucolytics: Reduce the viscosity of mucus and improve airflow (e.g. acetylcysteine)

title: Bronchodilators
detail:
• Stimulate beta-2 receptors in the lung, leading to the relaxation of the smooth muscle in the bronchiole, which results in better airflow
• Include albuterol, terbutaline, aminophylline, theophylline

title: Beta-receptor agonists
detail:
• Cause relaxation of smooth muscle, leading to bronchodilation
• Decrease histamine release through stabilization of the mast cell
• Albuterol is an example

title: Anticonvulsants
detail:
• Most common for long-term control of epileptic seizures are phenobarbital (first-line), potassium bromide (added if first-line not sufficient, but not in cats), and levetiracetam; all work by influencing NT release and decreasing seizure-related neuronal activity
• Status epilepticus and cluster seizures require immediate treatment—IV diazepam (a benzo tranq) is used to stop seizure; can also be administered rectally and nasally at home

title: Immunosuppressants
detail:
• Glucocorticoids: May be short- (hydrocortisone), intermediate- (prednisone/prednisolone), or long-acting (betamethasone/dexamethasone)
• Cyclosporine A
• Azathioprine
• Tacrolimus
• Chlorambucil

title: Anti-inflammatory drugs
detail:
• Glucocorticoids: cortisone, hydrocortisone, prednisone, etc.
• NSAIDs: carprofen, robenacoxib, meloxicam, etc.
• Using glucorticoids w NSAIDs is contraindicated due to GI risks (bleeding, ulceration, perforation)

title: Glucocorticoids
detail:
• Cause immunosuppression
• Commonly used to treat immune-mediated diseases in which the immune system attacks cells of the body
• Can be used to treat inflammation in musculoskeletal problems
• Can be used to shrink tumors
• Allergies will also respond to glucocorticoids
• Should not be used to treat infections due to immunosuppressant properties
• Might induce hyperadrenocorticism unless treatment includes destruction of the adrenal gland, at which point glucocorticoids are used as supplementation to replace what the adrenal gland would have produced

title: Dietary supplements and nutraceuticals
detail:
• Nutraceutical: Nondrug substance produced in purified or extracted form and administered orally
• Include S-adenosylmethionine, milk thistle, glucosamine, chondroitin

title: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
detail:
• Inability to produce sufficient amount of tears
• Tx w cyclosporine, which reduces inflammatory cells and increases number of mucin-secreting goblet cells

title: Mydriatic and miotic agents
detail:
• Mydriatic (pupil dilating) agents
• Tropicamide
• Miotic (pupil constricting) agents
• Pilocarpine and carbachol (given to glaucoma patients to transiently decrease intraocular pressure)

title: Chelation therapy
detail:
• Tx of heavy metal toxicity from lead, mercury, arsenic
• Incorporates binding (chelating) agents that bond w the metals so they can be discharged in urine
• Include calcium EDTA, succimer, dimercaprol, penicillamine
• Succimer can cross the blood-brain barrier, so able to bind to poison in the brain

title: Acetylcysteine
detail:
• Used to treat acetaminophen overdose
• Stimulates the production of glutathione and bind w NAPQI (the byproduct of acetaminophen metabolism), reducing toxic effects

title: Atropine
detail:
• Used to treat organophosphate poisoning (found in insecticides)
• Organophosphates interfere w breakdown of acetylcholine at cholinergic sites, causing muscarinic (salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, bradycardia, vomiting), nicotinic (weakness, paresis, stiffness, muscle tetany), and CNS signs (anxiety, hyperactivity, seizures, coma)
• Atropine addresses muscarinic and some CNS signs, not nicotine signs
• Atropine is an anticholinergic antidote—lowers secretions caused by the poisoning, expands airways that are constricted from its spasmodic effects
• Cats are particularly susceptible to organophosphate poisoning
• Can cause drooling, V/D, difficulty breathing due to spasms (laryngospasm, bronchospasm), tremors, muscle twitching, death

title: Ethylene glycol poisoning
detail:
• Ethylene glycol is antifreeze
• Signs include staggering, rapid pulse, abnormal behaviors, followed by vomiting, respiratory distress, agitation, seizures, acute renal failure, coma
• Tx w ethanol (drinking alcohol) and 4-methylpyrazole (Antizol-Vet) w/in 8 hours for best chance of survival

title: Rodenticide toxicity
detail:
• Rodenticides, like Warfarin, work by preventing recycling of vitamin K, which is used in the production of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X
• Tx w vitamin K supplementation
• Should be continued until effects of rodenticide wear off

title: Drugs for joint health in dogs
detail:
• Glucosamine: Produces glycosaminoglycan, which forms and repairs cartilage; supplements help replenish as it decreases w age
• Chondroitin: Main glycosaminoglycan; responsible for shock absorption and joint tissue health by providing elasticity and water retention in the cartilage; normally used in conjunction w glucosamine
• Chondroitin blocks the enzymes that try to destroy cartilage in the joints, glucosamine works to repair them

title: Antineoplastic agents (cytotoxic chemotherapy drugs)
detail:
• Work by seeking out any cell (healthy or neoplastic) that can multiply rapidly
• Starting dose based on blood volume, which is close to body surface in sq meters
• Classified as
• Alkylating agents
• Antimetabolites
• Plant alkaloids
• Antibiotics
• Hormonal agents

title: Alkylating agents
detail:
• Formed by an alkyl group and carbon-hydrogen compounds
• Can hinder growth by preventing DNA replication necessary for growth or by causing mispairing of nucleotides
• Include cisplatin (not for cats), carboplatin, chlorambucil, cyclophosphamide

title: Prodrugs
detail:
• Drugs that are inactive in their administered form
• Need to be altered in a way to become active—byproducts of the drug’s biotransformation are the active form
• Allows to increase bioavailability (usually improved GI absorption) and target specific cells (e.g. only a property unique to cancer cells activate it)
• Cyclophosphamide is an example—must be changed by the liver to activate the drug’s alkylating agents
• Enalapril becomes the active form enalaprilat
• Benazepril becomes the active form benazeprilat

title: Antimetabolites
detail:
• Interrupts normal metabolic processes like cell growth
• Analogs of purine and pyrimidine take the place of real ones, which are organic nucleotides necessary to sustain cell division, resulting in failure to replicate
• Include hydroxyurea (bone marrow or lymph node cancers), cytarabine (leukemia), methotrexate (breast, head, neck, lung, bone, blood cancers), 5-fluoroucil (bowel, breast, stomach, esophageal cancers; not for cats)
• Can lead to bone marrow suppression

title: Plant alkaloids
detail:
• Mitotic inhibitors (Vinca alkaloids) stop cellular mitosis
• Not target-cell specific
• Can be toxic—GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, alopecia

title: Antineoplastic antibiotics
detail: • Actinomycin D, mitoxantrone, doxorubicin, bleomycin—all created from Streptomyces

title: Antineoplastic hormonal agents
detail:
• Glucocorticosteroids (prednisone, dexamethasone)
• Signs of toxicity include PU/PD, immunosuppression, glucose intolerance, peptic ulcers, pancreatitis, hypokalemia, osteopenia, muscle wasting, cataracts

title: Safety data sheet
detail: • Safety, handling, clean-up, and disposal criteria for every drug used in the clinic

title: Controlled substances
detail:
• Prescription drugs with potential for addiction and abuse by humans
• Five schedules based on potential for abuse
	• I: High abuse potential, not used in vet med (heroine, LSD)
	• II:  High abuse potential, physical/psychic dependence (morphine, codeine, methadone, fentanyl, pentobarbital)
	• III:  Moderate abuse potential, more psychological dependence (buprenorphine, ketamine, tiletamine)
	• IV: Low abuse potential (phenobarbital, butorphanol, alfaxalone, diazepam)
• V:  Low abuse potential, no DEA limit on prescriptions (antitussives (codeine))

title: Controlled substances log
detail:
• Shows the balance on hand of each controlled substance
• Must be kept for 2 years
• Must include:
• Patient name
• Client name
• Date
• Drug name
• Drug amount used
• For injectables, the actual amount administered as well as the drawn-up amount
• Inventory must be checked regularly to make sure it matches the log

title: Vaccine storage
detail:
• Refrigerated at 35 – 45 F
• Dedicated refrigerator
• Modified live vaccines are heat sensitive
• Adjuvanted vaccines are sensitive to freezing—adjuvant and antigen will separate and form a precipitate that can cause inflammation at the admin site
• When drawn up, must be administered w/in 30 min

title: Veterinarian-client-patient relationship (VCPR)
detail:
• Must be established before prescription of drugs
	• Veterinarian has assumed responsibility for making medical judgments and client has agreed to follow his instructions
	• Veterinarian has sufficient knowledge of the animal to make a preliminary diagnosis
	• Veterinarian is available for follow-up in case of adverse reactions
	• Veterinarian provides oversight of treatment, compliance, and outcome
• Patient records are maintained

title: Prescription labels (information of labels for drugs dispensed to clients)
detail:
• Name, address, phone number of dispensing clinic/pharmacy
• Name of prescribing veterinarian
• Client’s name
• Pet’s identifying information (name and species)
• Date dispensed
• Directions for use
• Drug name, concentration, quantity
• Following statement for controlled drugs: “Fed. law prohibits transfer of this drug to any person other than the patient…”
• Must be provided in a child-resistant container

title: Elements of a prescription (required by law)
detail:
• Vet’s name, address, phone number
• Vet’s DEA registration number
• Vet’s signature
• Drug name, concentration, quantity
• Directions for use
• Client’s name and address
• Pet’s identify information (name and species)
• Any cautionary statements
• Number of refills (not allowed for Schedule II, limited to 5 times or 6 months (whichever comes first) for Schedule III and IV)
• For controlled drugs, vet’s name must be printed

title: Drug disposal
detail: • Controlled substances that have expired or been damaged are disposed thru reverse distributors authorized to dispose them

title: Crash cart
detail:
• Catheters, tape, syringes, needles, fluid bag, Ambu-bag, and emergency drugs and dosage chart should be available
• Emergency drugs include epinephrine, atropine, naloxone, lidocaine, doxapram
• Epinephrine for anaphylaxis and stimulating the heart during CPR
• Atropine for bradycardia and possibly CPR
• Lidocaine for cardiac arrhythmias
• Doxapram for stimulating breathing

title: Dosage
detail: • Amount of drug per kg body weight (mg/kg, mL/kg, tablets/kg)

title: Dose
detail:
• Amount of drug that will be given with each administration (mg, mL, units [U])
Dose (mg) = Weight (kg) x Dosage (mg/kg)
• Dose (mL) = Dose (mg) ÷ Concentration (mg/mL)

title: Syrup
detail: • Drug dissolved in liquid sugar

title: Emulsion
detail: • Suspension made w oil or fat

title: Elixir Tincture
detail: • Alcohol-based solutions

title: Dilution vs. solution
detail:
• Dilution: Occurs when ratio of substance to dilutant is decreased when dilutant is added to the solution; reduction of concentration occurs
• Solution: Mixture of substances made by dissolving solids or liquids in liquids; does not precipitate

title: Concentration of a solution
detail:
• Amount of solute dissolved in the solvent
• Expressed as v/v (liquids), w/v, or w/w (solids).
• Concentration (w/vol) of 1:100 = 1 g / 100 mL = 1% = 10 mg/mL

title: Strength of a solution
detail:
• Strength of a solution (w/v) = Concentration (g/mL) =
mass (g) ÷ volume (mL)
(multiply by 100 to find percent solution)

title: Stock solution
detail:
• Product of combining pure solution (100%) w a solvent thru dilution—solvent is mixed in to reduce the concentration of the solution
C2 x V2 = C1 x V1
Ex. Prepare 2 L of a 25% solution given a 50% solution and saline
C2 = Concentration of desired solution = 25%
V2 = Volume of desired solution = 2 L
C1 = Concentration of stock solution = 50%
V1 = ?

title: Drip rates
detail:
Drip Rate = Volume of solution (mL) x Drops (ggt)/mL
Time (seconds)
Ex. 1 L is to be administered over 4 hours using a 20-dr/mL set
Volume of solution = Amount to be administered = 1000 mL
Drops/mL = 20
Time = 4 x 60
Drip Rate = 1000 x 20 / 240

title: Drop factor
detail:
• Number of drops per cc or mL of fluid
• Dependent on the diameter of IV tubing
• Common factors are 15 ggt/mL and 10 ggt/mL (macro drips), and 60 gtt/mL (micro drip)
• gtt: guttae

title: Fluid rate
detail:
• Determined based on percent dehydration (fluid deficit), ongoing losses, and maintenance requirement
= %dehydration x weight in kg
+
vol of losses (estimated or actual)
+
40-60 mL x weight in kg

title: CRI
detail:
• Used to administer IV drugs over long periods of time or when the drug has a short half-life
• Added to a base solution; often IV fluids
M = (D x W x V) ÷ R
M = Amount of drug (mcg or mg) to be added to base solution
D = Dosage (mcg/kg/min or mg/kg/min)
W = weight (kg)
V = Volume of base solution (mL)
R = Infusion rate (mL/min

title: Factors affecting drug absorption
detail:
• Solubility of the drug
• Ionization tendency of the drug (pKa)
• pH of tissues
• Perfusion of tissues
• Volume of distribution (Vd)
• First pass effect

title: Systemic drug absorption
detail:
• Any medication given IV, IM, or SQ will be absorbed systemically
• Sucralfate is not absorbed systemically; it coats the esophagus and stomach and is not absorbed into the blood

title: First-pass effect
detail:
• Portion of a drug that is lost during the process of absorption, which typically happens in the intestinal wall and liver
• May cause large portions of drug to be readily metabolized before entering general circulation, necessitating a higher dose to be effective
• Injections used to by-pass this effect

title: Considerations for drug administration
detail:
• Vomiting patients should not be administered PO
• Catheter should be placed w a clean stick to administer chemotherapeutics, and a different vein should be used if a vein is blown (instead of going higher up) to avoid risk of extravasation of the drug

title: Bioavailability
detail:
• Fraction of a drug dose that reaches the bloodstream
• Drugs administered IV are 100% bioavailable (i.e., bioavailability of 1)
• Bioavailability is influenced by dosage form of the drug, vascularity of administration site, mechanism of absorption, and metabolism of the drug
• Bioavailability of same drug can change with route—butorphanol is 100% bioavailable IV but 20% bioavailable PO
• Drugs of plant origin (digoxin, atropine) are ineffective in cattle when administered orally because digestive microorganisms in the rumen, which will limit bioavailability

title: Five rights of drug administration
detail:
• Right to be the proper recipient (not to administer the drug to wrong patient)
• Right to receive proper medication (not to administer the wrong drug to the right patient)
• Right to receive proper dosage
• Right to receive drug via the proper route
• Right to receive medication on time

title: Extra-label use
detail:
• Allowed in 1994 under Animal Medicinal Drug Use Clarification Act (AMDUCA), illegal prior
• “Use of a drug in a manner that is not in accordance with the approved labeling”
• Includes use in another species, use for other indications, use at other dosage levels/frequencies/routes of administration
• Conditional upon a valid VCPR, absence of new approved drug w same active ingredient, documentation, and giving long withdrawal time
• FDA can prohibit ELU of some drugs (e.g., on food producing animals)
• Includes human drugs too

title: Drug compounding
detail:
• Manipulation of a drug other than as described on the label
• Classified as extra-label use
• Cannot be done from bulk chemicals (raw ingredients) or to produce a new drug
• Typically not legal to dispense compounded medications to be taken home by the client

title: Elimination of drugs
detail:
• Liver is the primary organ
• Uses enzymes to change or break down the drug, which is then called a metabolite
• Disposal thru urine, feces, sweat

title: Bound and unbound drugs
detail:
• Portion of the drug is bound to proteins in the blood, mostly albumin
• Bound portions are too large to move through fenestrations and into tissues, so only unbound portions will be distributed
• Important when highly protein-bound drugs are administered to patients with hypoproteinemia since less protein will mean more of the drug will be distributed, making side effects more likely

title: Drug clearance (Cl)
detail:
• A pharmacokinetic value describing drug elimination
• Rate at which a drug is removed from an organ or the body
• Expressed as volume of plasma cleared of drug per unit time (mL/minute)
• Used to measure efficiency of elimination and determine dosage regimen necessary to achieve a stable concentration in the blood (i.e., steady state—amount of drug administered equals amount of drug eliminated)

title: Half-life (t1/2)
detail:
• Time required for the amount of a drug in the body to decrease by 50%
• Each half-life lowers drug concentration by half of the level it was at the beginning of that half-life
• Estimates the duration of a drug’s effect, so used to estimate dosing interval
• Also used to establish withdrawal time in food-producing animals (i.e., period when food products contain unacceptable amounts of the drug—may cause allergies, antibiotic resistance)
• Time needed to reach steady state, or time required for 97% of the drug to be removed, is approximately 5x the half-life

title: Nervous system receptors
detail:
• Sympathetic (adrenergic) system receptors:
• Alpha receptors are stimulatory
• Beta receptors are inhibitory
• Parasympathetic (cholinergic) system receptors:
• Nicotinic receptors are found at the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscles and at the ganglionic synapses; activated by acetylcholine and nicotine
• Muscarinic receptors are found in the glands, heart, smooth muscle; activated by acetylcholine and muscarine

title: SLUD
detail: • Muscarine effects—salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation

title: Transporting molecules
detail:
• Pinocytosis: Cell drinking (active)
• Phagocytosis: Cell eating (active)
• Facilitated transport: Active transport w a carrier protein
• Passive transport: Molecules freely crossing the cell membrane

title: Nitrous oxide
detail:
• Diffuses into the alveoli and take the place of oxygen if used as an anesthetic
• Patient should be maintained on 100% oxygen for 5–10 min after gas is shut off to allow time for nitrous oxide to leave the alveoli and oxygen to take its place to avoid diffusion hypoxia

title: Halothane
detail: • Risk of malignant hyperthermia

title: Corticosteroid
detail:
• Corticosteroids have short-term side effects like polyuria, polyphagia, and immunosuppression, which can cause delayed healing
• Long-term effects include osteoporosis
• Corticosteroids mimic elevated cortisol levels in mares and cows, which are found at the beginning of parturition, leading to abortions if given during last weeks of gestation
• Include dexamethasone

title: Griseofulvin
detail:
• Fungistatic antibiotic
• Used to treat dermatophyte fungal infections in dogs and cats, and ringworm in horses

title: Clavamox
detail:
• Amoxicillin combined w clavulanic acid (combination is called a potentiated aminopenicillin)
• Antibiotic to which beta-lactamase–producing bacteria are not resistant
• Used to treat UTIs, skin and soft tissue infections in cats and dogs; canine periodontal disease, bacterial cystitis in female dogs, and hepatobiliary infections in cats and dogs

title: Tramadol
detail:
• Mu-receptor opiate-like agonist
• Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin
• Schedule IV drug, more recently became controlled (2014)
• Used as an alternative analgesic or adjunct for post-op or chronic pain in dogs and horses
• May cause anxiety, tremors, V/D, sedation

title: Blood-xxx barrier
detail:
• Brain
• Prostate
• Testicle
• Eye
• Joint
• Placenta

title: Induction in horses
detail:
• Detomidine, diazepam, and xylazine are commonly used
• Acepromazine causes persistent paraphimosis, increasing risk of injury

title: Cyclooxygenase (COX)
detail:
• Enzyme that synthesizes prostaglandin, which regulates inflammation, pain, blood clotting, and smooth muscle contraction to promote healing and homeostasis
• COX-1 maintains physiologic functions like modulation of renal blood flow, platelet function, and gastric mucosal integrity
• COX-2 is the induced form that is associated w tissue trauma and inflammation, as well as thermoregulation

title: Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)
detail:
• Solvent added to topical medications to allow penetration of the skin (carrier of drugs)
• Causes vasodilation when applied topically
• Also used to reduce acute swelling from trauma, and as an anti-inflammatory in otic preparations
• Gloves should be worn to prevent penetration of the skin of the person applying the medication

title: Methionine
detail:
• Urinary acifier
• Decreases urine pH, making it more acidic, leading to dissolving of any struvite stones present and prevention of formation of new stones
• Not used as much since acidifying diets

title: Penicillin
detail:
• Bactericidal
• Most gram-positive, some gram-negative bacteria
• Has a beta-lactam ring that can be degraded by the beta lactamases, rendering it ineffective
• Methicillin, cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, oxacillin are beta-lactamase-resistant
• Doesn’t become available in cerebrospinal fluid, joints, and milk
• Penicillin G is inactivated by stomach, so not given PO
• Kills normal GI flora and allows overgrowth of Clostridium, which causes severe, life-threatening diarrhea in rabbits and guinea pigs

title: Side effects of sulfonamides
detail:
• Crystal formation in kidneys leading to hematuria
• Decreased tear production causing keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
• Allergic reactions, especially in Doberman pinschers
• Development of thrombocytopenia and leukopenia
• So not commonly used
